Package infodynamics.measures.continuous.symbolic

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorSymbolic

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.symbolic.TransferEntropyCalculatorSymbolic
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, TransferEntropyCalculator, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorSymbolic
extends TransferEntropyCommon
implements TransferEntropyCalculator

    Computes the differential transfer entropy (TE) between two univariate double[] time-series of observations using symbolic TE estimation. For details on symbolic TE estimation, see Staniek and Lehnertz (below).

    TE was defined by Schreiber (below). This estimator is realised here by extending TransferEntropyCommon.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculator, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to TransferEntropyCalculatorSymbolic().
    • A restricted set of properties are available, see setProperty(String, String);

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    • M. Staniek, K. Lehnertz, "Symbolic Transfer Entropy", Physical Review Letters 100, 158101 (2008)
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                        java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception

        Set properties for the kernel TE calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • TransferEntropyCalculator.L_PROP_NAME -- embedding length for the source past history vector (default value 1)
        • any valid properties for TransferEntropyCommon.setProperty(String, String), noting that we are explicitly overriding it to allow TransferEntropyCalculator.L_PROP_NAME here.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Overrides:
        setProperty in class TransferEntropyCommon
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon

        Computes the local values of the implemented channel measure, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local TE values. If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then this time-series will have zero entries until the source and destination embedding vectors are defined.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        Returns:

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an empirical (bootstrapped) distribution of what the given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations methods etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Not implemented yet
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by a call to getNumObservations() for the given measure) containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where e.g. the newOrderings don't supply arrays of the correct length matching the number of observations that we have.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."
